rename.from: Comments no longer associated with an STI models base class
rename.to: Comments no longer associated with an STI model's base class

body: @johnmaxwell do you know the commit form the change? There could be a reason for this change. I'm basically agree with your argumentation, but I want to know the reason for that before I say anything about a rollback.
Okay, thanks for the feedback.  I hadn't checked on the origin of the change.  I will do that and get back with you.

So the change of creating associating with the subclass instead of the base class happened in 68593b67, but the commit doesn't give me much idea about motivation.   Since polymorphic associations are made unique by their ID, it's not like you risk ambiguity by using the STI base class for the association.  Using the specific subclass makes the comment-to-model relationship more breakable and breaks compatibility with 0.6.3. I don't really see the upside.

/cc: @brennovich 
Here's the issue associated with the commit: #2596

Both argumentations have a true aspect. At the moment I can't say this or that is the best.

Is there a way to support both ways?
I guess it _could_ be configurable of course, but I'm still not sure I understand the counterpoint to associating with the base class.  What is it?
I will take a look on that later

Well, I have vaguely memories about those changes :/

I'm pretty sure that I did it intentionally. I understand that it's a breaking change, although I believe that both behaviors are right... At the moment and the context the association with the actual class instead of the `base_class` did make more sense...

We need to keep in mind that the actual behavior is now being used on users' applications, I definitely vote for make if configurable :)

The Rails convention for polymorphic associations is to associate with the base class on assignment, not the subclass: 

> Using polymorphic associations in combination with single table inheritance (STI) is a little tricky. In order for the associations to work as expected, ensure that you store the base model for the STI models in the type column of the polymorphic association. To continue with the asset example above, suppose there are guest posts and member posts that use the posts table for STI. In this case, there must be a type column in the posts table.
> -- http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActiveRecord/Associations/ClassMethods.html#module-ActiveRecord::Associations::ClassMethods-label-Polymorphic+Associations

This is what happens automatically when you attempt to assign a STI subclass to a polymorphic belongs_to association: Rails populates the associations _type field with the base class.

Based on what I see in #2596, it looks like it was changed to get the cosmetic benefit of having the resource's type displayed in the Comments index.  Doesn't seem like a good reason to break this convention.
@johnmaxwell I think you are right, but I will have one other opinion on this. But feel free to create a PR to change the behavior. @seanlinsley what do you think about this?

It isn't just about cosmetics... Anyway, I understand the convention, and think that we should rely on them. Although, in the case of the **AA Comments** feature, I believe that the information of which subtype is is important, it can make easier to display information, build reports, etc.

Perhaps we can add a new column `resource_subtype`, that way we can follow up conventions and satisfy real use cases. Do you guys think it is feasible? :)
@johnmaxwell would you like to work on this?

Guys, by just reverting it we'll commit the same error as before, maybe there are end users relying on this behavior now, don't you agree? I can work this weekend to get it configurable(or add a new column as I suggested above), can we hold until then?
